case_id: State of Punjab v. Ramdev Singh (2003)
facts: Marriage between Gurdeep Kaur (deceased) and Ramdev Singh (Respondent/Accused) solemnized on 04.03.1990.
Allegations surfaced soon after marriage that Ramdev Singh and his family started harassing Gurdeep Kaur for dowry, specifically demanding a scooter and cash.
Due to alleged harassment and demands, Gurdeep Kaur returned to her parental home.
Attempts were made by the deceased's family to convene a Panchayat (village council meeting) for resolution, but Ramdev Singh reportedly refused to participate.
Gurdeep Kaur was subsequently sent back to her matrimonial home by her parents.
The deceased wrote letters to her parents detailing the continued harassment and dowry demands.
On 28.01.1991 (within approximately 11 months of marriage), Gurdeep Kaur died an unnatural death by strangulation in her matrimonial home.
FIR was lodged by PW3, Balbir Singh (father of the deceased).
Post-mortem examination confirmed the cause of death as asphyxia due to strangulation.
Key prosecution witnesses included PW3 (father) and PW4 (mother) who testified regarding the dowry demands and harassment.
The Trial Court convicted Ramdev Singh under Section 304-B IPC and sentenced him to 7 years of rigorous imprisonment.

On appeal, the High Court acquitted Ramdev Singh, primarily finding that the prosecution failed to establish that the alleged dowry harassment occurred 'soon before' the death and casting doubt on the reliability of parental testimony.
The State of Punjab filed an appeal against the High Court's acquittal order before the Supreme Court.

prosecution_arguments.argument: The High Court erred in acquitting the accused; all ingredients of Section 304-B IPC were established beyond reasonable doubt.
precedents: Satvir Singh v. State of Punjab (2001) 8 SCC 633 (Interpretation of 'soon before death' and linkage with Section 113-B Evidence Act)
Kans Raj v. State of Punjab (2000) 5 SCC 207 ('Soon before' does not mean 'immediately before'; contemplates a reasonable period based on facts)
Pawan Kumar v. State of Haryana (1998) 3 SCC 309 (Cruelty contemplated under S. 304-B/498A includes harassment for dowry)
elements: Death occurred otherwise than under normal circumstances (strangulation - proved by post-mortem).
Death occurred within seven years of marriage (occurred within 11 months).
Deceased was subjected to cruelty or harassment by her husband (or relatives).
Such cruelty or harassment was for, or in connection with, any demand for dowry.
Such cruelty or harassment was meted out 'soon before her death'.

counter_arguments.loophole: Lack of specific, dated instance of cruelty immediately preceding the death, potentially weakening the 'soon before death' nexus.
supporting_precedents: Balwant Singh v. State of Punjab (2004) 7 SCC 724 (Emphasis on proximate link for 'soon before death')
Surinder Singh v. State of Haryana (2014) 4 SCC 129 (Mere past harassment without proximate link is insufficient for Section 304-B)
Tarsem Singh v. State of Punjab (2008) 16 SCC 155 (Requirement of proximity test for 'soon before death')

prosecution_arguments.argument: The High Court wrongly discarded the credible and consistent testimonies of the deceased's parents (PW3, PW4) regarding dowry demands and harassment, which were corroborated by letters written by the deceased.
precedents: State of U.P. v. Ramesh Prasad Misra (1996) 10 SCC 360 (Testimony of close relatives, if found truthful and credible, cannot be discarded solely on the ground of relationship)
Gura Singh v. State of Rajasthan (2001) 2 SCC 205 (Parental testimony in dowry cases is natural and often the best evidence available)
Trimukh Maroti Kirkan v. State of Maharashtra (2006) 10 SCC 681 (Circumstantial evidence, including conduct and testimonies of relatives, must be considered holistically)
elements: Proof of cruelty/harassment linked to demand

counter_arguments.loophole: Parents are inherently interested witnesses; potential for embellishment or bias. Letters might express general unhappiness, not necessarily dowry harassment directly linked to the period 'soon before death'.
supporting_precedents: Kali Ram v. State of H.P. (1973) 2 SCC 808 (Burden of proof squarely on prosecution; suspicion cannot replace proof)
M. Narsinga Rao v. State of A.P. (2001) 1 SCC 691 (Evidence of interested witnesses requires careful scrutiny and preferably corroboration)
Surinder Kumar v. State of Haryana (2011) 10 SCC 173 (Need for caution while evaluating testimony of interested witnesses in dowry cases)

prosecution_arguments.argument: Once the foundational facts (unnatural death within 7 years, dowry harassment) were proven, the presumption under Section 113-B of the Indian Evidence Act was triggered, shifting the burden onto the accused to rebut it, which he failed to do.
precedents: State of Karnataka v. Dattaraj (2001) 9 SCC 181 (Nature and scope of presumption under Section 113-B)
Hem Chand v. State of Haryana (1994) 5 SCC 709 (Once ingredients of 304-B are established, court is bound to invoke 113-B presumption)
Sher Singh @ Partapa v. State of Haryana (2015) 3 SCC 724 (Detailed analysis of Section 113-B presumption and its rebuttal)
elements: Failure of accused to discharge the shifted burden.

counter_arguments.loophole: The presumption under Section 113-B is rebuttable. The High Court's finding that 'soon before death' was not proven essentially meant the foundational facts for triggering the presumption were not fully established.
supporting_precedents: Baijnath v. State of M.P. (2017) 1 SCC 101 (Presumption under 113-B arises only after prosecution proves foundational facts beyond reasonable doubt)
Ashok Kumar v. State of Haryana (2010) 12 SCC 350 (Accused can rebut the presumption by showing preponderance of probabilities that he did not commit the offence)
Major Singh v. State of Punjab (2015) 5 SCC 201 (Standard of proof for rebuttal by accused is preponderance of probability)

defense_arguments.argument: The High Court rightly acquitted, as the prosecution failed to establish a proximate and live link between the alleged dowry harassment and the death; the crucial element 'soon before death' was not proven.
edge_cases: Interpretation of 'soon before death' requires demonstrable temporal proximity, not just historical or sporadic instances of harassment.
Absence of any specific incident of demand or cruelty reported immediately prior to the death.
precedents: Kamesh Panjiyar @ Kamlesh Panjiyar v. State of Bihar (2005) 2 SCC 388 (Requirement of proximate and live link between cruelty and death)
Shamnsaheb M. Multtani v. State of Karnataka (2001) 2 SCC 577 (Distinction between Section 304-B and Section 306 IPC criteria)
Bhim Singh v. State of Uttarakhand (2002) 10 SCC 461 ('Soon before death' implies that the interval should not be long, breaking the causal link)

defense_arguments.argument: The testimonies of the deceased's parents (PW3, PW4) are unreliable as they are interested witnesses and their statements lack independent corroboration regarding specific acts of cruelty proximate to the time of death.
edge_cases: Potential for exaggeration due to grief and animosity.
General allegations of past demands without specific dates or instances close to the death date.
precedents: Appabhai v. State of Gujarat (1988) Supp SCC 241 (Principles for appellate courts while dealing with appeals against acquittal; presumption of innocence reinforced)
Sunil Kumar Sambhudayal Gupta (Dr.) v. State of Maharashtra (2010) 13 SCC 657 (Need for qualitative evidence; Court must separate grain from chaff)
Raman Kumar v. State of Punjab (2009) 16 SCC 35 (Requirement for careful scrutiny of relative witnesses' testimony)

defense_arguments.argument: The presumption under Section 113-B of the Evidence Act was either not triggered due to failure to prove all foundational facts (especially 'soon before death') or was successfully rebutted by demonstrating the absence of proximate cruelty.
edge_cases: The burden to prove foundational facts rests solely on the prosecution.
Acquittal by High Court indicates it found the presumption rebutted or inapplicable based on evidence.
precedents: Baijnath v. State of M.P. (2017) 1 SCC 101 (Prosecution must first prove foundational facts beyond reasonable doubt for presumption to arise)
Amar Singh v. State of Rajasthan (2010) 9 SCC 94 (Presumption under 113-B is rebuttable)
Mangat Ram v. State of Haryana (2014) 12 SCC 595 (Rebuttal can be through evidence led by defence or by weaknesses in prosecution case itself)

judgment.outcome: Appeal allowed. High Court judgment set aside. Trial Court judgment convicting Ramdev Singh under Section 304-B IPC and sentencing him to 7 years RI restored. (Actual historical outcome)
reasoning: The Supreme Court held that the High Court adopted an erroneous interpretation of 'soon before her death'. It does not mean 'immediately before'.
Continuous harassment and cruelty over a period, if systemic and related to dowry, can constitute cruelty 'soon before death' if the interval is not such as to snap the causal link.
The evidence of PW3 and PW4 (parents) was found credible and consistent, corroborated by the letters written by the deceased indicating persistent dowry demands and harassment.
The High Court's reasons for discarding the parental testimony were considered infirm.
Given the unnatural death (strangulation) within 11 months of marriage and the established persistent dowry harassment, the foundational facts for Section 304-B were met.
Consequently, the presumption under Section 113-B of the Indian Evidence Act was correctly invoked by the Trial Court.
The accused failed to rebut the statutory presumption by preponderance of probabilities.
The High Court's acquittal was deemed unjustified and based on a misinterpretation of law and misappreciation of evidence, warranting interference by the Supreme Court.
